At early stage of development the concept of `acceptedParents` was introduce as a way to enhance the modeling tools provided by Proteus. I was decided not to show these archetypes in the archetype menu.
Showing an archetype with parent restrictions in the archetype menu does not make sense because it will be disabled most of the time unless you select the specific accepted parent (or parents). The context menu of each object is used to show these kind of archetypes but, in order to avoid excesive complex context menus, just the explicitly accepted classes are shown in the context menu.
This creates a situation where if an archetype has a restriction like `acceptedParents="classA"` and `classA` does not explicitly accept the archetype class as child, it will not be shown anywhere in the application. For archetype menu handling, these archetypes that are available in the menu are called "first level archetypes" because the accept `:Proteus-any` as accepted parent.
